Experimental Section  General Reagents and chromatography solvents were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification, apart from THF, which was distilled in present of benzophenone and sodium wire. 1H NMR spectra recorded in D2O or (CD3)2SO were referenced to residual H2O and CHD2S(O)CD3  at 4.79 and 2.50 ppm, respectively. 13C NMR spectra recorded in (CD3)2SO were referenced to (CD3)2SO at 39.5ppm. 13C NMR spectra recorded in D2O were referenced to external (CH3)2SO at 39.39 ppm. MALDI-TOF mass spectra were recorded by using an Applied Biosystems Voyager DE-Pro mass spectrometer with 2,4,6-trihydroxylacetophenone (THAP) as the matrix. Positive molecular ions were usually detected as proton, sodium or potassium adducts for the compounds reported herein.  ESI mass spectra were recorded on a Finnigan LCQ Duo mass spectrometer  2. Synthesis of cavitands    11 10 2  2.1. Synthesis of cavitand 10. Cavitand 11 (0.691 g, 0.365 mmol)1 was dried in high vacuum for 2h and dissolved in 8 mL dry THF under Argon. TBAF!3H2O was (0.920 g, 2.9 mmol) was dried at 58 oC in high vacuum for 2h and dissolved in 15 mL dry THF.  The TBAF solution was added to the solution of 11 in THF and the reaction mixture was stirred under Argon for 4h. Several drops of water were added to the reaction mixture and THF was removed in vacuum. The solid residue suspended in 20 mL water and sonicated. The resulting mixture was filtered and the solid was washed with water and dried, which yielded the crude product as yellowish solid. The solid was purified by silica gel column chromatography using 7:3 CH2Cl2:IPA (v/v). The product was crystallized from THF/acetonitrile to give 10 as a white solid (0.183 g, 54%).   1H NMR ((CD3)2SO, 400MHz, 25 oC): "H (ppm): 10.12 (s, 4H, CHO), 7.86 (s, 4H, H-aryl), 5.90 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 4H, OCHHouterO), 4.76 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 4H, Hmethine), 4.22 (m, 8H, OH, OCHHinnerO), 3.41 (dd, J1 = 11.0 Hz, J2 = 5.9 Hz, 8H, (CH2)3CH2OH), 2.36 (dd, J1 = 13.8 Hz, J2 = 6.8 Hz, 8H, CH2(CH2)3OH), 1.56 (m, 8H, CH2CH2(CH2)2OH), 1.34 (m, 8H, (CH2)2CH2CH2OH) 13C NMR ((CD3)2SO, 100MHz, 25 oC): "C (ppm): 189.73, 153.96, 139.07, 127.25, 123.54, 99.62, 60.70, 35.90, 32.33, 28.48, 23.93. HR-Maldi-Tof Ms: m/z: 959.3430, Calcd for C52H56O16Na: 959.3460  S3  Figure S1: 1H NMR spectrum ((CD3)2SO; 400 MHz; 25oC) of cavitand 10.

S5  2.2. Synthesis of cavitand 2 Cavitand 10 (0.210 g, 0.224 mmol) was dried in high vacuum for 2h and dissolved under Argon in 2 mL of dry DMSO containing several beads of molecular sieves. Py!SO3 (0.285 g, 1.80 mmol) was added and the reaction solution was stirred under Argon for 15min. The reaction mixture was quenched with 20 mL of water and was adjust pH~8 with Na2CO3 aq.. The solvent was removed in high vacuum. The solid residue was suspended in 1.5 mL of DMSO, sonicated and filtered to remove the salts. The resulting solution was added drop-wise with stirring to 50 mL CH3CN upon which 2 crystallized. 0.22 g of 2 were isolated by filtration as a white solid (73% yield).  1H NMR (D2O, 500MHz, 25oC): In D2O, an 9:1 equilibrium mixture between the aldehyde groups and their hydrates is observed. S8   3. Synthesis of hemicarceplexes. Stock solutions of individual diamines 3a-c (0.1M) were prepared in D2O.  3.1 Synthesis of hemicarceplex 1a"1,4-dimethoxybenzene (Procedure A)  Cavitand 2 (0.002 mmol, 2.7mg) was dissolved in 550 米L D2O in an NMR tube. 1,4-Dimethoxylbenzene (1mg) was added and the mixture was shaken for several minutes.  Ethylen-1,2 diamine 3a (44 米L of 0.1 M solution) was added. The reaction solution was shaken for several minutes and allowed to stand overnight at room temperature after which an equilibrium is reached containing 81% 1a"1,4-dimethoxybenzene by NMR integration. 1H NMR (D2O, 500MHz, 25 oC): "H (ppm): 8.21 (s, 8H, CH=N), 7.67 (s, 8H, Haryl), 5.79 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 8H, OCHHouterO), 5.58 (s, 4H, Haryl, guest), 4.88 (t, J = 8.3 Hz, 8H, Hmethine), 4.2 (d, J = 7.1 Hz, 8H, OCHHinnerO), 4.14 (t, J = 5.7 Hz, 16H, (CH2)3CH2OSO3Na), 3.62 (s, 16H, CH=NCHHouter), 2.52 (m, 16H, CH2(CH2)3OSO3Na), 1.88 (m, 16H, (CH2)2CH2CH2OSO3Na), 1.51 (m, 16H, CH2CH2(CH2)2OSO3Na), -0.35 (s, 6H, CH3 guest) 13C NMR (D2O, 125MHz, 25 oC): "C (ppm): 158.2, 153.8, 139.5, 125.1, 123.5, 115.6, 113.4, 99.6, 70.3, 63.0, 56.0, 39.4, 37.1, 28.9, 24.3 ESI-MS(m/z): 951.5 (-3), 708.0 (-4), 561.8 (-5), 464.5 (-6), 394.8 (-7);   Calcd: m/z 951.2 (C112H120N8O48S8Na5!C8H10O2)3-, 707.6 (C112H120N8O48S8Na4!C8H10O2)4-, 561.5 (C112H120N8O48S8Na3!C8H10O2)5-, 464.1 (C112H120N8O48S8Na2!C8H10O2)6-, 394.5 (C112H120N8O48S8Na!C8H10O2)7-    Figure S8: 1H NMR spectrum (D2O; 500 MHz; 25oC) of 1a"1,4-dimethoxybenzene. DOI: 10.1002/chem.201200602Assembly of Water-Soluble, Dynamic, Covalent Container Molecules andTheir Application in the Room-Temperature Stabilization ofProtoadamanteneZhihua Lin, Junling Sun, Bisera Efremovska, and Ralf Warmuth*[a]IntroductionIn recent years, molecular container compounds have re-ceived much attention due to their ability to confine one ormore guest molecules inside their cavities.[1]Compartmen-talization combined with unique molecular recognitionproperties form the basis for applications of molecular con-tainers in drug delivery,[2]scavenging of environmental haz-ards,[3]gas and hydrocarbon storage and separation,[4]andmost notably as nanoreactors.[5]As a consequence of guestconfinement, reactions carried out inside molecular contain-ers often proceed with a different regiochemistry as com-pared to the bulk,[6]and in some cases are million-fold accel-erated.[7]On the other extreme, encapsulation increases lon-gevity of otherwise fleeting reactive intermediates underambient conditions.

[4a,d,e,11,12]We became interested in testing the suitabilityof dynamic octaimine hemicarcerands 1a每cas molecular re-action flasks for the photochemical generation and stabiliza-tion of highly strained, reactive species, such as the Bredtolefins adamantene 4and protoadamantene 5(Schemes 1and 2).[13]Abstract: The thermodynamically con-trolled reactions of water-soluble tetra-formylcavitand 2with two equivalentsof H2N ACHTUNGTRENNUNG(CH2)nNH2(n=2每4) in thepresence of a suitable templating guestgive hemicarceplexes 1a每c﹞guest, theyield of which depends on the matchbetween size and shape of the guestand that of the inner phase. Thesehemicarceplexes are dynamic and dis-sociate upon addition of acid andreform upon basification. In water,they exchange guests through tempora-ry hydrolysis of imine bonds. To test1bas molecular reaction flask, 3-nora-damantyldiazirine 6was encapsulatedand photolyzed at 350 nm to produceBredt olefin protoadamantene 5and 1-noradamantyldiazomethane 8in a 4:1ratio. Encapsulated protoadamanteneis stable for days at room temperaturein (CD3)2SO/CD3CN ( t1/2=5.5 days)and has a lifetime of several minutes inD2O.Keywords: Bredt olefins ﹞dynamiccovalent chemistry ﹞host每guestchemistry ﹞molecular containercompound ﹞reactive intermediates[a] Dr. Z. Lin, J. Sun, B. Efremovska, Dr. R.
